Exploring Selective Layer Fine-Tuning in Federated Learning

Yuchang Sun1 , Yuexiang Xie2, Bolin Ding2, Yaliang Li2, Jun Zhang1
1Hong Kong University of Science and Technology 2Alibaba Group
yuchang.sun@connect.ust.hk, {yuexiang.xyx, bolin.ding,yaliang.li}@alibaba-inc.com
eejzhang@ust.hk Work done as an intern at Alibaba Group.
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising paradigm for fine-tuning foundation models using distributed data in a privacy-preserving manner. Under limited computational resources, clients often find it more practical to fine-tune a selected subset of layers, rather than the entire model, based on their task-specific data. In this study, we provide a thorough theoretical exploration of selective layer fine-tuning in FL, emphasizing a flexible approach that allows the clients to adjust their selected layers according to their local data and resources. We theoretically demonstrate that the layer selection strategy has a significant impact on model convergence in two critical aspects: the importance of selected layers and the heterogeneous choices across clients. Drawing from these insights, we further propose a strategic layer selection method that utilizes local gradients and regulates layer selections across clients. The extensive experiments on both image and text datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy compared with several baselines, highlighting its advances in identifying critical layers that adapt to the client heterogeneity and training dynamics in FL.

1 Introduction

Foundation models [1], including BERT [2], GPT [3, 4], CLIP [5, 6], LLaMA [7], and so on [8, 9], have attracted considerable attention due to their exceptional ability in handling complex tasks [10]. When it comes to practical deployments of these models in specialized fields, fine-tuning with domain-specific data becomes critical. Nevertheless, the distributed nature of data across various users and organizations presents a challenge for centralized storage and training, as it may lead to severe privacy concerns and incur additional transmission costs. Such issues have positioned federated learning (FL) [11] as a promising paradigm to fine-tune foundation models, aligning model enhancement with privacy preservation [12, 13].

Generally, FL aims to learn a global model through a collaborative process where clients perform local training and upload the parameter updates to a central server for aggregation. Given that clients have limited resources [14, 15], such as computational power, communication bandwidth, and available memory, it becomes impractical for them to fine-tune the entire foundation model. Two kinds of solutions have recently emerged to tackle this challenge. The first solution employs parameter-efficient fine-tuning techniques [16, 17, 18, 19], which introduces additional modules integrated into foundation models and updates these modules with domain-specific data while keeping the parameters of the foundation model frozen. The second one is selective model fine-tuning [20, 21, 22, 23], which only selects an impactful subset of parameters for optimization to streamline the fine-tuning process under resource constraints.

This study focuses on selective model fine-tuning as it is particularly well-suited to address the inherent heterogeneity in FL, i.e., the data heterogeneity and device heterogeneity [24, 25, 26]. Specifically, clients involved in FL have non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data distribution and different system resources, leading to the need to customize fine-tuning strategies to such discrepancies. For example, clients with limited computation resources may opt to update only a fraction of the model, while those with sufficient resources and high-quality data prefer fine-tuning a large portion of the model to enhance performance. Selective model fine-tuning enables clients to adjust the chosen part of the model to be updated based on their own capabilities, providing a flexible and advanced solution to mitigating sub-optimal issues induced by the heterogeneity in FL.

The exploration of selective model fine-tuning within the context of FL, is still in its early stages. Previous studies [23, 21, 27, 28] have concentrated on designing static strategies for subnetwork selection to improve model fine-tuning performance, without adequately considering heterogeneity among clients. To fulfill this gap, in this paper, we provide a comprehensive theoretical analysis on selective model fine-tuning in FL, focusing on a general scenario where clients are allowed to choose different layers for local training and vary their choices across different training epochs, called selective layer fine-tuning. Specifically, we formulate the optimization objective of selective layer fine-tuning in FL, and provide insights on effectively determining critical layers to achieve model convergence. Building on these insights, we further propose a novel layer selection strategy that leverages local gradients and the regulation of unified selections.

Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We study a practical FL setup where clients choose to fine-tune some layers of the model, with arbitrary layer selection that may vary among clients and across different training epochs. We theoretically analyze such a training scheme and investigate the impact of layer selection. The analytical results show that the selected layers affect the convergence performance with two critical aspects, namely the importance of layers and heterogeneous choices across clients.

  • •

    Building on the theoretical analysis, we formulate the optimization problem of selective layer fine-tuning considering the limited and diverse resource budgets of clients. Inspired by the solution to this optimization problem, we propose an effective strategy for selecting layers for fine-tuning that are well-suited for the local data and available resources at clients.

  • •

    We conduct experiments to compare the proposed layer selection strategy with baseline methods on both image and text datasets. The experimental results demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed strategy in achieving better model performance, highlighting that the proposed strategy can find critical layers for fine-tuning while considering the client heterogeneity and training dynamics in FL. 111The source codes are available at https://anonymous.4open.science/r/fed_selected_tune/.

2 Related Works

Various approaches have been proposed to properly select a subset of parameters for fine-tuning foundation models within centralized training, including optimizing a non-structured mask matrix [20, 21, 22, 23, 29, 30, 31, 32] and adopting layer-wise selection strategies [31, 32, 27, 33]. For example, [20] suggests updating the parameters in a stochastic manner based on the Bernoulli distribution, while [31, 32] showcase that fine-tuning the top few layers achieves competitive model performance in downstream tasks. Moreover, [27] proposes to select layers according to their gradient statistics.

Recent studies have extended the selective fine-tuning techniques to FL scenarios [34, 35, 36, 37]. Specifically, researchers [38, 28] investigate layer-wise network decomposition to achieve selective model fine-tuning on clients. However, these works fail to offer methodologies for adaptive and dynamic layer selection that take into account the heterogeneous characteristics of clients. In addition, personalized FL algorithms [39, 40] propose to train different subnetworks on clients towards better local models. Different from previous studies, we focus on providing an in-depth understanding of selective layer fine-tuning in FL, considering the heterogeneity from the perspective of client resources and local data distributions.

3 Problem Formulation

Federated Learning

We consider an FL system with a central server and N𝑁N clients (denoted by the set 𝒩={1,…,N}𝒩1…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,\dots,N\}), where each client has a private dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} consisting of di=|𝒟i|subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖d_{i}=|\mathcal{D}_{i}| data instances. The server owns a pretrained foundation model θ∈ℝP𝜃superscriptℝ𝑃\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{P}, containing P𝑃P trainable parameters and L𝐿L layers with the index set ℒ={1,2,…,L}ℒ12…𝐿\mathcal{L}=\{1,2,\dots,L\}. The server aims to fine-tune this foundation model based on the clients’ datasets 𝒟={𝒟i}i∈𝒩𝒟subscriptsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑖𝒩\mathcal{D}=\{\mathcal{D}_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{N}} but does not directly access these datasets. The learning goal is formally given as:

minθ∈ℝP⁡f​(θ)=∑i=1Nαi​fi​(θ),subscript𝜃superscriptℝ𝑃𝑓𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝜃\min_{\theta\in\mathbb{R}^{P}}f(\theta)=\sum_{i=1}^{N}\alpha_{i}f_{i}(\theta), (1)

where αi=di∑j=1Ndjsubscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑑𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscript𝑑𝑗\alpha_{i}=\frac{d_{i}}{\sum_{j=1}^{N}d_{j}} denotes the relative sample size, and fi​(θ)=1di​∑ξ∈𝒟iFi​(θ;ξ)subscript𝑓𝑖𝜃1subscript𝑑𝑖subscript𝜉subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃𝜉f_{i}(\theta)=\frac{1}{d_{i}}\sum_{\xi\in\mathcal{D}_{i}}F_{i}(\theta;\xi) denotes the local training objective of client i𝑖i. Here we use Fi​(θ;ξ)subscript𝐹𝑖𝜃𝜉F_{i}(\theta;\xi) to define the (possibly non-convex) loss function computed by the model θ𝜃\theta on data sample ξ𝜉\xi. The training process of FL is divided into T𝑇T training epochs. In each epoch t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], the server chooses a subset of clients 𝒮tsuperscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}^{t}, and sends the up-to-date global model θtsuperscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{t} to these clients for local training.

Selective layer fine-tuning in FL

An overview of selective layer fine-tuning in FL is illustrated in Figure 1. Due to resource limitations, clients tend to update some of the layers in the local training process rather than the entire global model. Formally, we define a masking vector 𝐦it∈{0,1}Lsuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡superscript01𝐿\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}\in\{0,1\}^{L} for each client i𝑖i. The l𝑙l-th element 𝐦it​(l)superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡𝑙\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}(l) equals 111 if the l𝑙l-th layer is selected to be updated in the t𝑡t-th training epoch, and 𝐦it​(l)=0superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡𝑙0\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}(l)=0 otherwise. Accordingly, the selected layer set of client i𝑖i is denoted by ℒit≜{l∈ℒ|𝐦it​(l)=1}≜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡conditional-set𝑙ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡𝑙1\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}\triangleq\{l\in\mathcal{L}|\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}(l)=1\}, and the set for all selected layers in the t𝑡t-th training epoch is denoted by ℒt=⋃i∈𝒮tℒitsubscriptℒ𝑡subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡\mathcal{L}_{t}=\bigcup_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}. The choice of selected layer sets has a substantial effect on training performance, which will be discussed in detail later.

After determining the selected layer set ℒitsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}, clients initialize the local model according to the global model sent by the server, i.e., θit,0=θtsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡0superscript𝜃𝑡\theta_{i}^{t,0}=\theta^{t}, and train the local model for τ𝜏\tau local steps using the mini-batch SGD algorithm [11, 41, 42]. For local step k∈[τ]𝑘delimited-[]𝜏k\in[\tau], client i𝑖i samples a batch of data instances ξit,ksuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡𝑘\xi_{i}^{t,k}, and calculates the gradients for the selected layers, which is given as222∇lF​(θ)subscript∇𝑙𝐹𝜃\nabla_{l}F(\theta) represents the gradient of a function F​(θ)𝐹𝜃F(\theta) w.r.t. the parameters of the l𝑙l-th layer in model θ𝜃\theta.:

∑l∈ℒitgi,l​(θit,k;ξit,k)=∑l∈ℒit∇lFi​(θit,k;ξit,k).subscript𝑙superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡𝑘subscript𝑙superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡subscript∇𝑙subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡𝑘\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}}g_{i,l}(\theta_{i}^{t,k};\xi_{i}^{t,k})=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}}\nabla_{l}F_{i}(\theta_{i}^{t,k};\xi_{i}^{t,k}). (2)

Notably, the local gradient calculation pertains solely to the layers within the subset ℒitsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}. Afterward, the local model is updated with the learning rate η𝜂\eta:

θit,k=θit,k−1−η​∑l∈ℒitgi,l​(θit,k−1;ξit,k−1),∀k∈{1,2,…,τ}.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘1𝜂subscript𝑙superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡𝑘1for-all𝑘12…𝜏\theta_{i}^{t,k}=\theta_{i}^{t,k-1}-\eta\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}}g_{i,l}(\theta_{i}^{t,k-1};\xi_{i}^{t,k-1}),\forall k\in\{1,2,\dots,\tau\}. (3)

The accumulated model update in local training is summarized as:

Δit=1η​(θit,0−θit,τ)=∑k=0τ−1∑l∈ℒitgi,l​(θit,k;ξit,k).superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑡1𝜂superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡0superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝜏1subscript𝑙superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡𝑘\Delta_{i}^{t}=\frac{1}{\eta}(\theta_{i}^{t,0}-\theta_{i}^{t,\tau})=\sum_{k=0}^{\tau-1}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}}g_{i,l}(\theta_{i}^{t,k};\xi_{i}^{t,k}). After local training, clients upload their model updates Δit,i∈𝒮tsuperscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑡𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡\Delta_{i}^{t},i\in\mathcal{S}^{t} to the server. The server performs federated aggregation among these model updates and optimizes the global model accordingly:

and

θt+1=θt−η​Δt.superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡𝜂superscriptΔ𝑡\theta^{t+1}=\theta^{t}-\eta\Delta^{t}. (6)

Inspired by previous studies [11, 43], the aggregation weights in selective layer fine-tuning are defined based on the data ratio and the masking vectors, which are formally given as:

wi,lt={di∑{j∈𝒮t|𝐦jt​(l)=1}dj,if ​𝐦it​(l)=1,0,otherwise.superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑡casessubscript𝑑𝑖subscriptconditional-set𝑗superscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑗𝑡𝑙1subscript𝑑𝑗if superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡𝑙10otherwise.w_{i,l}^{t}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}\frac{d_{i}}{\sum_{\{j\in\mathcal{S}^{t}|\mathbf{m}_{j}^{t}(l)=1\}}d_{j}},&\text{if }\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}(l)=1,\\ 0,&\text{otherwise.}\end{array}\right. (7)

The details of the training process are summarized in Appendix A.

4 Which Layers Should Be Selected For Fine-Tuning?

The aforementioned training process provides substantial flexibility in selective layer fine-tuning, namely, clients are allowed to select different layers for local training and adjust their choices in different training epochs. Such flexibility enables clients to tailor their local training to their data and resources, providing feasible solutions for handling the heterogeneity in FL.

However, without a well-designed strategy for layer selection, the optimization of the global model in FL could be severely hindered, potentially leading to a suboptimal solution or even failure in convergence. As a result, researchers have proposed several useful strategies for layer selection in recent years, including:

  • •

    All clients select the same layer set for fine-tuning [39, 20, 22, 30, 32], i.e., ℒit=ℒjt,∀i≠jformulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑗𝑡for-all𝑖𝑗\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}=\mathcal{L}_{j}^{t},\forall i\neq j;

  • •

    Clients fix their selections across different training epochs [44, 40], i.e., ℒit1=ℒit2,∀t1,t2∈[T]formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖subscript𝑡1superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖subscript𝑡2for-allsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2delimited-[]𝑇\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t_{1}}=\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t_{2}},\forall t_{1},t_{2}\in[T].

These strategies for layer selection are proposed based on the insights drawn from experts’ experience, serving as special instantiations of the selected layer sets ℒitsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}. It is worth noting that these experience-driven strategies might not consistently yield optimal results in various FL applications, particularly considering the client heterogeneity. This leads to an essential question: How to effectively determine the task-specified layer selection strategy among a large search space of possible options? In the rest of this section, we provide a theoretical analysis to answer this question.

4.1 Theoretical Analysis

Following previous theoretical analysis in FL [41, 42, 43], we begin with some necessary assumptions.

Assumption 4.1.

(γ𝛾\gamma-Smoothness) There exists a constant γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 such that for any θ,θ′∈ℝP𝜃superscript𝜃′superscriptℝ𝑃\theta,\theta^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{P}, ‖∇fi​(θ)−∇fi​(θ′)‖2≤γ​‖θ−θ′‖2,∀i∈𝒩formulae-sequencesubscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝜃∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃′2𝛾subscriptnorm𝜃superscript𝜃′2for-all𝑖𝒩\|\nabla f_{i}(\theta)-\nabla f_{i}(\theta^{\prime})\|_{2}\leq\gamma\|\theta-\theta^{\prime}\|_{2},\forall i\in\mathcal{N}.

For analyzing the effect of each layer on the model convergence, we give several assumptions for the gradient with respect to each layer l𝑙l.

Assumption 4.2.

(Unbiased and variance-bounded stochastic gradient) The stochastic gradient gi,l​(θt;ξit)subscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡g_{i,l}(\theta^{t};\xi_{i}^{t}) on a randomly sampled batch of data ξitsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡\xi_{i}^{t} is an unbiased estimate of the full-batch gradient, i.e., 𝔼​[gi,l​(θt;ξit)]=∇lfi​(θt)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡subscript∇𝑙subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\mathbb{E}[g_{i,l}(\theta^{t};\xi_{i}^{t})]=\nabla_{l}f_{i}(\theta^{t}). Besides, there exist constants σl>0,∀l∈ℒformulae-sequencesubscript𝜎𝑙0for-all𝑙ℒ\sigma_{l}>0,\forall l\in\mathcal{L} such that ‖gi,l​(θt;ξit)−∇lfi​(θt)‖2≤σl2,∀i∈𝒩formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡subscript∇𝑙subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2for-all𝑖𝒩\|g_{i,l}(\theta^{t};\xi_{i}^{t})-\nabla_{l}f_{i}(\theta^{t})\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{l}^{2},\forall i\in\mathcal{N} and ∑l∈ℒtσl2≤σ2subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑙2superscript𝜎2\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\sigma_{l}^{2}\leq\sigma^{2}.

The non-IID data owned by clients causes diverse gradients. In the following assumption, we state the diversity of each layer’s gradient.

Assumption 4.3.

(Gradient diversity) There exist constants κl>0,∀l∈ℒformulae-sequencesubscript𝜅𝑙0for-all𝑙ℒ\kappa_{l}>0,\forall l\in\mathcal{L} such that ‖∇lf​(θt)−∇lfi​(θt)‖2≤κl2,∀i∈𝒩formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormsubscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript∇𝑙subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝜅𝑙2for-all𝑖𝒩\left\|\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})-\nabla_{l}f_{i}(\theta^{t})\right\|^{2}\leq\kappa_{l}^{2},\forall i\in\mathcal{N}.

Here we first consider a case where τ=1𝜏1\tau\!=\!1 to simplify the analysis without affecting the insights on layer selection. The detailed analysis for the generalized case, i.e., τ>1𝜏1\tau\!>\!1, is provided in Section B.3.

Compared with the theoretical analysis for the standard FL settings [45, 43], there exist three additional challenges in selective layer fine-tuning. Firstly, since each client only updates some layers during the local training process, the aggregated gradient is no longer an unbiased estimate of the local gradient ∇fi​(θt)∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla f_{i}(\theta^{t}), i.e.,

𝔼​[Δit]=∑l∈ℒit∇lfi​(θt)≠∇fi​(θt),𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑡subscript𝑙superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡subscript∇𝑙subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{i}^{t}]=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}}\nabla_{l}f_{i}(\theta^{t})\neq\nabla f_{i}(\theta^{t}), (8)

where the inequality holds unless all layers are selected for fine-tuning, i.e., ℒit=ℒsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡ℒ\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}=\mathcal{L}. Secondly, since a certain layer may not be selected by all the clients, the aggregated gradient of this layer is not equivalent to the gradient computed based on the global loss function (∑l∈ℒt∇lf​(θt)subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})), which is given as:

𝔼​[Δt]=∑l∈ℒt∑i∈𝒮twi,lt​∇lfi​(θt)≠∑l∈ℒt∇lf​(θt),𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑡subscript∇𝑙subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\Delta^{t}]=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}w_{i,l}^{t}\nabla_{l}f_{i}(\theta^{t})\neq\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t}), (9)

where the inequality holds unless all clients select the same subset of layers. Last but not least, the aforementioned gaps vary across different training epochs, making it rather complicated in the theoretical analysis.

To link the aggregated and desired gradients, we define a surrogate objective function representing the underlying loss function optimized by the clients, which is given as:

hlt​(θ)≜∑i∈𝒮twi,lt​fi​(θ).≜superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡𝜃subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑡subscript𝑓𝑖𝜃h_{l}^{t}(\theta)\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}w_{i,l}^{t}f_{i}(\theta). (10)

In essence, the layer-wise gradient of this objective function represents the update of the aggregated global update ΔtsuperscriptΔ𝑡\Delta^{t}. This relationship is elaborated in the following lemma.

Lemma 4.4.

With 4.2, we have:

𝔼​[Δt]=∑l∈ℒt∇lhlt​(θt),𝔼delimited-[]superscriptΔ𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡\mathbb{E}[\Delta^{t}]=\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t}), (11)

where the expectation is with respect to mini-batch data sampling.

Proof.

We rewrite both sides of Equation 11 by using the definitions in Equations 5 and 10, and apply 4.2 to obtain the result. ∎

As aforementioned, the underlying loss function hlt​(θ)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡𝜃h_{l}^{t}(\theta) deviates from the desired global loss function f​(θ)𝑓𝜃f(\theta), which hinders the optimization of the global model and may lead to suboptimal model performance. Such deviation can be quantified by the difference between the underlying update ∑l∈ℒt∇lhlt​(θt)subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t}) and the global gradient ∇f​(θt)∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla f(\theta^{t}), i.e.,

ℰt≜‖∇f​(θt)−∑l∈ℒt∇lhlt​(θt)‖2.≜subscriptℰ𝑡superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t}\triangleq\left\|\nabla f(\theta^{t})-\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t})\right\|^{2}. (12)

The term ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t} can be further decomposed using the Jensen’s inequality into two parts:

ℰt≤2​‖∇f​(θt)−∑l∈ℒt∇lf​(θt)‖22+2​‖∑l∈ℒt∇lf​(θt)−∇lhlt​(θt)‖22.subscriptℰ𝑡2superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡222superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡22\displaystyle\mathcal{E}_{t}\leq 2\left\|\nabla f(\theta^{t})-\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})\right\|_{2}^{2}+2\left\|\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})-\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t})\right\|_{2}^{2}. (13)
Remark 4.5.

These two terms in the right-hand side (RHS) of (13) can be interpreted as follows: (i) The first term is the difference between the gradient w.r.t. all layers and the gradient w.r.t. the selected layers. The value of this term becomes smaller when the selected layers have larger gradients; (ii) The second term represents the mismatch between the desired gradient computed by all clients (i.e., ∇lf​(θt)=∑i∈𝒩αi​∇lfi​(θt)subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑖𝒩subscript𝛼𝑖subscript∇𝑙subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\alpha_{i}\nabla_{l}f_{i}(\theta^{t})) and the underlying update computed by partial clients (i.e., ∇lhlt​(θt)=∑i∈𝒮twi,lt​∇lfi​(θt)subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑡subscript∇𝑙subscript𝑓𝑖superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t})=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}w_{i,l}^{t}\nabla_{l}f_{i}(\theta^{t})), resulting from different layer choices among clients. If some layer is selected by all clients, its corresponding term in this term can be diminished.

For a better understanding, the following lemma shows an upper bound for the value of ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t}.

Lemma 4.6.

With 4.3, we have:

ℰt≤2​[‖∑l∉ℒt∇f​(θt)‖2]⏟ℰt,1+2​∑l∈ℒtχ𝐰t,l∥α​κl2⏟ℰt,2,subscriptℰ𝑡2subscript⏟delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡2subscriptℰ𝑡12subscript⏟subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript𝜒conditionalsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙𝛼superscriptsubscript𝜅𝑙2subscriptℰ𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t}\leq 2\underbrace{\Bigg{[}\Bigg{\|}\sum_{l\notin\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla f(\theta^{t})\Bigg{\|}^{2}\Bigg{]}}_{\mathcal{E}_{t,1}}+2\underbrace{\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\chi_{\mathbf{w}_{t,l}\|\mathbf{\alpha}}\kappa_{l}^{2}}_{\mathcal{E}_{t,2}}, (14)

where χ𝐰t,l∥α≜∑i∈𝒩(wi,lt−αi)2αi≜subscript𝜒conditionalsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙𝛼subscript𝑖𝒩superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑙𝑡subscript𝛼𝑖2subscript𝛼𝑖\chi_{\mathbf{w}_{t,l}\|\mathbf{\alpha}}\triangleq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\frac{(w_{i,l}^{t}-\alpha_{i})^{2}}{\alpha_{i}}.

The proofs can be found in Section B.1.

Next we aim to analyze the impact of layer selection on the convergence of the global model. Following previous studies [46, 41], we consider an algorithm to have achieved convergence if it converges to a stationary point of the global loss function, i.e., if its expected squared gradient norm mint∈[T]⁡𝔼​[‖∇f​(θt)‖22]subscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡22\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\theta^{t})\right\|_{2}^{2}\right] is zero. The following theorem and corollary show the convergence of the proposed selective layer fine-tuning framework for FL.

Theorem 4.7.

Define a constant C≜1−4​η​L>0≜𝐶14𝜂𝐿0C\triangleq 1-4\eta L>0. With Assumptions 4.1-4.3, we have:

mint∈[T]⁡𝔼​[‖∇f​(θt)‖22]≤2η​C​T​[f​(θ0)−f​(θ∗)]+2​γ​ηC​σ2+1T​∑t=1T(1γ​η​C+2)​(ℰt,1+ℰt,2).subscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡222𝜂𝐶𝑇delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝜃0𝑓superscript𝜃2𝛾𝜂𝐶superscript𝜎21𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇1𝛾𝜂𝐶2subscriptℰ𝑡1subscriptℰ𝑡2\displaystyle\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\theta^{t})\right\|_{2}^{2}\right]\leq\frac{2}{\eta CT}\left[f(\theta^{0})-f(\theta^{*})\right]+\frac{2\gamma\eta}{C}\sigma^{2}+\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(\frac{1}{\gamma\eta C}+2\right)(\mathcal{E}_{t,1}+\mathcal{E}_{t,2}). (15)

The proofs can be found in Section B.2.

Corollary 4.8.

With the commonly selected learning rate η=𝒪​(1T)𝜂𝒪1𝑇\eta=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right), the RHS of (15) except the last term becomes zero as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty. Therefore, FL with selective layer fine-tuning may only oscillate around a stationary point of the global loss function with a non-zero error floor 𝒪​(ℰt,1+ℰt,2)𝒪subscriptℰ𝑡1subscriptℰ𝑡2\mathcal{O}(\mathcal{E}_{t,1}+\mathcal{E}_{t,2}).

According to Theorem 4.7 and Corollary 4.8, the training performance of the global model is degraded by the increase of ℰt,1+ℰt,2subscriptℰ𝑡1subscriptℰ𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t,1}+\mathcal{E}_{t,2}, in the following aspects:

  • •

    The term ℰt,1subscriptℰ𝑡1\mathcal{E}_{t,1} indicates that it might lead to a suboptimal global model if layers with large gradient norms were not selected for fine-tuning.

  • •

    The term ℰt,2subscriptℰ𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t,2} shows that the consistent selections among clients promote the convergence of the global model. Specifically, if the l𝑙l-th layer has large gradient diversity κlsubscript𝜅𝑙\kappa_{l}, implying significant objective bias among clients, reducing the weight divergence χ𝐰t,l∥αsubscript𝜒conditionalsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙𝛼\chi_{\mathbf{w}_{t,l}\|\mathbf{\alpha}} helps to alleviate this term.

These findings highlight that the layer selection strategy that minimizes both terms can achieve better convergence of the global model. However, minimizing these two terms simultaneously may lead to contradictory selection decisions. Moreover, the optimal solution for minimizing the sum of ℰt,1+ℰt,2subscriptℰ𝑡1subscriptℰ𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t,1}+\mathcal{E}_{t,2} is inaccessible, since the ground-truth values are intractable in practice. To resolve these challenges, in the next subsection, we propose a strategy to adaptively select layers for clients and promote the learning performance of the global model.

4.2 Layer Selection Strategy

Based on the above analysis, we need to determine the selected layer sets {ℒti}superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑡𝑖\{\mathcal{L}_{t}^{i}\} that minimize the values of ℰt,1subscriptℰ𝑡1\mathcal{E}_{t,1} and ℰt,2subscriptℰ𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t,2}. As both terms are hard to compute directly, we first design an approach to estimate their values.

To minimize ℰt,1subscriptℰ𝑡1\mathcal{E}_{t,1}, we prefer selecting layers with larger gradients, which can be achieved by maximizing the value of ∑l∈ℒt‖∇lf​(θt)‖22subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡22\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\|\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})\|_{2}^{2}. Since the norm of the global gradient ∇lf​(θt)subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t}) is unknown, we estimate it by using the sum of stochastic local gradients, expressed as ∑i∈𝒮t‖gi,l​(θt;ξit)‖22subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡22\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}\|g_{i,l}(\theta^{t};\xi_{i}^{t})\|_{2}^{2}. Meanwhile, forcing the same layer selection among clients can reduce the value of χ𝐰t,l∥αsubscript𝜒conditionalsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑙𝛼\chi_{\mathbf{w}_{t,l}\|\mathbf{\alpha}} and thus alleviate the term ℰt,2subscriptℰ𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t,2}. For this purpose, we introduce the regularization term ∑j≠i‖𝐦it−𝐦jt‖1subscript𝑗𝑖subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑗𝑡1\sum_{j\neq i}\|\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}-\mathbf{m}_{j}^{t}\|_{1} into the optimization objective. Therefore, the selection of layers is determined by solving the following optimization problem:

(P1)​max{𝐦it}∑i∈𝒮t∑l∈ℒit‖gi,l​(θt;ξit)‖22−λ2​∑i∈𝒮t∑j≠i‖𝐦it−𝐦jt‖12, s.t. ℛ​(𝐦it)≤Rit,∀i∈𝒮t.(P1)subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑙superscriptsubscriptℒ𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡22𝜆2subscript𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑗𝑖superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐦𝑗𝑡12 s.t. formulae-sequenceℛsuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡for-all𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡\textbf{(P1)}\begin{aligned} \max_{\{\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}\}}&\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{i}^{t}}\|g_{i,l}(\theta^{t};\xi_{i}^{t})\|_{2}^{2}-\frac{\lambda}{2}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}}\sum_{j\neq i}\|\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}-\mathbf{m}_{j}^{t}\|_{1}^{2},\\ \text{ s.t. }&\mathcal{R}(\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t})\leq R_{i}^{t},\quad\forall i\in\mathcal{S}^{t}.\end{aligned}

Here λ≥0𝜆0\lambda\geq 0 is a weighting constant. Specifically, a large λ𝜆\lambda forces consistent selection across clients, while λ=0𝜆0\lambda=0 allows for independent choices among clients. The constraint in Problem (P1) ensures that the total cost of the selected layers meets the clients’ local resource budgets Ritsuperscriptsubscript𝑅𝑖𝑡R_{i}^{t}, and the cost function ℛ​(⋅)ℛ⋅\mathcal{R}(\cdot) is typically a linear function of 𝐦itsuperscriptsubscript𝐦𝑖𝑡\mathbf{m}_{i}^{t}.

Solving Problem (P1) further gives an effective layer selection strategy for clients. At the beginning of a training epoch, each participating client i∈𝒮t𝑖superscript𝒮𝑡i\in\mathcal{S}^{t} evaluates the current global model θtsuperscript𝜃𝑡\theta^{t} on a batch of local data and obtains the layer-wise gradient gi,l​(θt;ξit),∀l∈ℒsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡for-all𝑙ℒg_{i,l}(\theta^{t};\xi_{i}^{t}),\forall l\in\mathcal{L}. Subsequently, clients upload the norms of these gradients ‖gi,l​(θt;ξit)‖2,∀l∈ℒsubscriptnormsubscript𝑔𝑖𝑙superscript𝜃𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝑡2for-all𝑙ℒ\|g_{i,l}(\theta^{t};\xi_{i}^{t})\|_{2},\forall l\in\mathcal{L}, which are L𝐿L-dimensional vectors, to the server. With these values, the server can optimize the selected layer sets for clients by solving Problem (P1).

In general, the proposed layer selection strategy leads to client-specific layer sets, determined based on the estimated gradient norms. Meanwhile, a hyper-parameter λ𝜆\lambda is used to regulate the extent to which clients are encouraged to select the same layer. In the next section, we empirically demonstrate the benefits of the proposed strategy in effectively identifying critical layers and achieving better model performance than existing methods.

Discussions on costs

The proposed layer selective algorithm requires computing and uploading the gradients of the selected layers, whose costs are much less than those of full model fine-tuning. To be more specific, when clients select R𝑅R layers for fine-tuning, the proposed method achieves a reduction in transmission and computational costs to RL𝑅𝐿\frac{R}{L} and L​ττ+L−1𝐿𝜏𝜏𝐿1\frac{L\tau}{\tau+L-1}, respectively. For example, when fine-tuning a CLIP model on the CIFAR-10 dataset, the proposed layer selection algorithm demands merely 8.3% of the transmission cost and 12% of the computation cost associated with full model fine-tuning while achieving competitive performance. The detailed analysis and numerical comparisons of the computation and communication costs are provided in Appendix C.

5 Experiments

5.1 Settings

Datasets & Models

We conduct a series of experiments on several widely-used image classification datasets, including CIFAR-10 [47] and DomainNet [48], text classification dataset, i.e., XGLUE-NC [49], and five benchmark question-answering (QA) datasets, including SCIQ [50], OpenbookQA [51], PIQA [52], ARC-Easy and ARC-Challenge [53] datasets, as summarized in Section D.1. As for the splitting of datasets, inspired by previous studies [54, 55], we consider two commonly observed data heterogeneity among clients: (i) Label skew: adopting Dirichlet distribution to allocate data samples of the CIFAR-10 dataset; (ii) Feature skew: adopting naturally domain shift on the DomainNet, XGLUE-NC, and QA datasets. Specifically, each QA dataset is equally divided into two subsets, with each client possessing one subset of samples from one of the five datasets. We adopt the CLIP model [5] for image classification tasks and the multi-lingual XLM-Roberta-Base [56] model on the XGLUE-NC dataset. In addition, we train a LLaMA-2-7B [7] model on the QA dataset.

Server & Clients

In the experiments, we set up an FL system with a central server and N=100𝑁100N=100 clients. In each training epoch, the server randomly selects a subset of 202020 clients, and broadcasts the up-to-date model to these clients for local training. Besides, there are N=10𝑁10N=10 clients in the QA task and five clients are randomly chosen for training in each epoch. The resource budgets of clients are limited, which are quantified as the maximum number of layers they can fine-tune in the local training. For example, we use Ri=1subscript𝑅𝑖1R_{i}=1 to indicate that the resource of client i𝑖i cannot afford fine-tuning more than 1 layer. The resource budgets can be identical or heterogeneous among clients.

Baselines

We compare the proposed layer selection strategy with several competitive baselines, including: (i) Top [31, 32]: Clients only fine-tune the top few layers (near the output) based on their task-specific data; (ii) Bottom [27]: Clients only fine-tune the bottom few layers (near the input) based on their task-specific data, which can be beneficial for the tasks with input-shift; (iii) Both [57]: Clients fine-tune an equal proportion of both the top and bottom layers, which shows the effectiveness for large language models; (iv) SNR [58]: Clients fine-tune the layers with higher signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) values, defined as the ratio of the mean of gradient elements to their variance; (v) RGN [59, 27]: Clients fine-tune the layers with higher relative gradient norm (RGN) values, defined as the ratio of gradient norm to the parameter norm; (vi) Moreover, we consider Full model fine-tuning, i.e., training the entire model, as the performance benchmark. More implementation details can be found in Section D.2.

5.2 Comparisons

We conduct experiments with the identical resource scenario and the heterogeneous resource scenario.

Identical resource scenario

We first consider clients with identical computational resources, i.e., clients select the same number of layers (Ri=R,∀i∈𝒩formulae-sequencesubscript𝑅𝑖𝑅for-all𝑖𝒩R_{i}=R,\forall i\in\mathcal{N}) for fine-tuning. The experimental results are shown in Table 1. From the model performance (accuracy) on the CIFAR-10 and DomainNet datasets, we observe that the proposed strategy demonstrates notable superiority over partial layer fine-tuning baselines. Specifically, fine-tuning only one layer of the CLIP model achieves comparable performance with tuning the entire model, since the CLIP model is sufficiently powerful to extract useful features and thus requires less training on task-specific data. This also reveals that selective layer fine-tuning well meets the performance requirement within the resources of clients.

On text datasets, including XGLUE-NC and QA, the proposed layer selection strategy and RGN demonstrate similar performance, both surpassing other baseline methods (especially Top and Both) by noticeable margins. One potential explanation for this phenomenon could be that they result in similar layer selections, indicating that updating layers with higher relative gradient norms is more beneficial than other strategies, which is consistent with previous study [27]. Moving a forward step, the proposed method adopts a flexible and dynamic layer selection strategy instead of fixed strategies, which leads to competitive performance.

Heterogeneous resource scenario

Further, we conduct experiments with heterogeneous clients, i.e., clients have different local resources and thus tend to select different numbers of layers for fine-tuning. Such a heterogeneous resource scenario is more practical [24, 25] and brings additional challenges for selective layer fine-tuning. Inspired by previous studies [41, 60], the number of layers to be fine-tuned, denoted as Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} for client i𝑖i, is sampled from a truncated half Normal distribution within [1,4]14[1,4].

The experimental results are shown in Table 2, from which we observe that the proposed strategy consistently shows superiority over all the baseline methods on all the datasets. Compared with baselines, the proposed strategy allows clients to flexibly determine the proper number of layers to be tuned and effectively find the most important layers. This advantage arises from enabling clients with sufficient resources to prioritize the selection of more critical layers instead of being restricted to layers in fixed positions. Overall, these experimental results demonstrate the advantage of the proposed strategy when handling heterogeneity in real-world FL applications.

5.3 Visualization of Selected Layers

For a better understanding on the proposed layer selection strategy, we visualize the selected layers on different datasets in Figure 2. When fine-tuning the CLIP model on the CIFAR-10 dataset, it can be observed that the focus is primarily on updating a few top layers, indicating that the low-level features (related to middle and bottom layers) are transferable from pre-trained data to downstream tasks. In comparison, the DomainNet dataset, characterized by a significant domain shift, necessitates extensive tuning of the middle layers in the CLIP model. Furthermore, on the XGLUE-NC dataset, we observe a clear progression of selected layers for fine-tuning, with a shift from the top layers progressively down to the bottom layers. Such a pattern is markedly different from the trend observed in the image datasets. One possible reason lies in the intrinsic differences between the modalities of text and image data. These results highlight the necessity for adaptive layer selection and adjustment strategies in FL to accommodate varying dataset properties and domain shifts.

6 Conclusions

In this paper, we study a practical FL setting for fine-tuning foundation models, where clients are allowed to optimize a subset of layers using their task-specific data. We carefully consider the impact of both data heterogeneity and device heterogeneity across clients, providing a comprehensive theoretical analysis of the optimization objective of selective layer fine-tuning and global model convergence. The theoretical analysis offers insights into how the selected layers influence global model training and highlights the role of layer importance and client heterogeneity. We further propose a novel strategy for layer selection that considers the local data and available resources at clients. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed strategy outperforms baseline strategies in improving the global model training performance and even matches full model fine-tuning performance in some scenarios, showing the potential for more efficient and tailored real-world FL applications of the proposed layer selection strategy.

Lemma B.1.

With 4.1, we have:

𝔼​[f​(θt+1)]−𝔼​[f​(θt)]≤12​γ​ℰt+𝔼​⟨∑l∈ℒt∇lhlt​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩⏟𝒯1+γ​𝔼​[‖θt+1−θt‖2]⏟𝒯2.𝔼delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡1𝔼delimited-[]𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡12𝛾subscriptℰ𝑡subscript⏟𝔼subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝒯1𝛾subscript⏟𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡2subscript𝒯2\mathbb{E}[f(\theta^{t+1})]-\mathbb{E}[f(\theta^{t})]\leq\frac{1}{2\gamma}\mathcal{E}_{t}+\underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left\langle\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t}),\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\right\rangle}_{\mathcal{T}_{1}}+\gamma\underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\right\|^{2}\right]}_{\mathcal{T}_{2}}. (16)
Proof.

We begin with analyzing the loss decay by using γ𝛾\gamma-smoothness in 4.1 as follows:

≤\displaystyle\leq 𝔼​⟨∇f​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩+γ2​𝔼​[‖θt+1−θt‖2]𝔼∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡𝛾2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\langle\nabla f(\theta^{t}),\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\rangle+\frac{\gamma}{2}\mathbb{E}[\left\|\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\right\|^{2}] (18)

=\displaystyle= 𝔼​⟨∇f​(θt)−∑l∈ℒt∇lhlt​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩⏟𝒯0+𝔼​⟨∑l∈ℒt∇lhlt​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩⏟𝒯1+γ2​𝔼​[‖θt+1−θt‖2]⏟𝒯2.subscript⏟𝔼∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝒯0subscript⏟𝔼subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝒯1𝛾2subscript⏟𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡2subscript𝒯2\displaystyle\underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left\langle\nabla f(\theta^{t})-\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t}),\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\right\rangle}_{\mathcal{T}_{0}}+\underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left\langle\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t}),\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\right\rangle}_{\mathcal{T}_{1}}+\frac{\gamma}{2}\underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\right\|^{2}\right]}_{\mathcal{T}_{2}}. By Young’s inequality, we upper bound the term 𝒯0subscript𝒯0\mathcal{T}_{0} as:

𝒯0=subscript𝒯0absent\displaystyle\mathcal{T}_{0}= 𝔼​⟨∇f​(θt)−∑l∈ℒt∇lhlt​(θt),θt+1−θt⟩𝔼∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡1superscript𝜃𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left\langle\nabla f(\theta^{t})-\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t}),\theta^{t+1}-\theta^{t}\right\rangle (21)

∎

B.1.2 Analyzing ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t}: Proof of Lemma 4.6

In this subsection, we prove the result in Lemma 4.6.

We begin with decomposing the term ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t} using the Jensen’s inequality as:

ℰt≤2​‖∇f​(θt)−∑l∈ℒt∇lf​(θt)‖22⏟ℰ~t,1+2​‖∑l∈ℒt∇lf​(θt)−∇lhlt​(θt)‖22⏟ℰ~t,2.subscriptℰ𝑡2subscript⏟superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡22subscript~ℰ𝑡12subscript⏟superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript∇𝑙superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑙𝑡superscript𝜃𝑡22subscript~ℰ𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t}\leq 2\underbrace{\|\nabla f(\theta^{t})-\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})\|_{2}^{2}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{E}}_{t,1}}+2\underbrace{\|\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})-\nabla_{l}h_{l}^{t}(\theta^{t})\|_{2}^{2}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{E}}_{t,2}}. (24)

For the first term ℰ~1,tsubscript~ℰ1𝑡\tilde{\mathcal{E}}_{1,t}, we directly obtain:

ℰ~1,t=𝔼​[‖∇f​(θt)−∑l∈ℒt∇lf​(θt)‖2]=𝔼​[‖∑l∉ℒt∇lf​(θt)‖2].subscript~ℰ1𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡subscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝑙subscriptℒ𝑡subscript∇𝑙𝑓superscript𝜃𝑡2\tilde{\mathcal{E}}_{1,t}=\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\theta^{t})-\sum_{l\in\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})\right\|^{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\sum_{l\notin\mathcal{L}_{t}}\nabla_{l}f(\theta^{t})\right\|^{2}\right]. (25)

Afterwards, we derive the value of ℰ~2,tsubscript~ℰ2𝑡\tilde{\mathcal{E}}_{2,t} as follows:

B.3 Convergence Analysis for Multi-Step Case

Appendix C Discussion on Computational and Communication Costs

Computational cost

Since all methods require the same forward operations, we focus on comparing the computational cost of backward operations in different methods. Consider that each client selects a layer to fine-tune a model with L𝐿L layers. For simplicity, we assume each layer requires b𝑏b FLOPs of backward operations. The average computational cost of the proposed layer selection method is calculated as:

Costsel=b​(L−1)⏟Select+b​τ⏟Fine-tune=b​(τ+L−1),subscriptCostselsubscript⏟𝑏𝐿1Selectsubscript⏟𝑏𝜏Fine-tune𝑏𝜏𝐿1\text{Cost}_{\text{sel}}=\underbrace{b(L-1)}_{\text{Select}}+\underbrace{b\tau}_{\text{Fine-tune}}=b(\tau+L-1), (70)

where τ𝜏\tau represents the local training steps. For comparison, fully fine-tuning a model requires the computational cost of:

Costfull=b​L​τ=L​ττ+L−1​Costsel.subscriptCostfull𝑏𝐿𝜏𝐿𝜏𝜏𝐿1subscriptCostsel\text{Cost}_{\text{full}}=bL\tau=\frac{L\tau}{\tau+L-1}\text{Cost}_{\text{sel}}. (71)

Thus, the proposed method takes a much lower computational cost than the full model fine-tuning, and the cost reduction is proportional to the number of layers and local training steps.

Meanwhile, the selection step of our method introduces slightly additional costs of L−1τ​L​Costfull𝐿1𝜏𝐿subscriptCostfull\frac{L-1}{\tau L}\text{Cost}_{\text{full}}, which can be further reduced by evaluating the model on a smaller volume of data or making the selection decision at a lower frequency.

Communication time

The communication time is determined by the transmitted bits of different methods. The proposed method only transmits the selected layers, which is much less than uploading the full model. For example, assuming that different layers have the same number of parameters, the communication cost of the proposed method is 1L1𝐿\frac{1}{L} of full model fine-tuning.

Cost of fine-tuning specific layers

When a layer is selected for fine-tuning, the client performs the forward operation through the whole model to obtain the loss and then conducts the backward operation to compute the gradient with respect to the selected layer. The gradient has the same shape as the weights of the selected layer, and thus the required FLOPs are proportional to the number of parameters in this specific layer. Since all methods require the same forward operations, we focus on comparing the computational cost of backward operations in different methods.

Empirical observation

The following table compares the computational cost (in TFLOPs) and communication cost (in transmitted MBits) of the proposed method with the full model fine-tuning. The numbers in brackets represent the cost of the layer selection strategy. The results show that the proposed method significantly reduces the computational cost and communication costs. Besides, the layer selection strategy takes as low as 3.4% of the computational cost.

Summarization

To summarize, the computational cost and communication cost/time of the proposed method are much lower than the full model fine-tuning. Besides, the empirical observations demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces the computational and communication costs.

Appendix D Experimental Details

We implement all methods with PyTorch and run experiments on Nvidia V100 GPUs. For fair comparisons, we adopt the same training epochs and hyper-parameters for all methods.

D.1 Training Tasks

To evaluate the methods in various scenarios with different non-IID patterns, we consider two image classification tasks and two text classification tasks.

The image classification tasks include:

  • •

    CIFAR-10 [47]: In this training task, we consider the label-skewed case where P​(yi)𝑃subscript𝑦𝑖P(y_{i}) is different among clients. Following previous works [26], we adopt Dirichlet allocation with concentration parameter α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 among clients.

  • •

    DomainNet [48]: DomainNet contains six domains of data samples, including clipart, real, sketch, infograph, painting, and quickdraw. In this training task, we consider the varying feature case where P​(xi|yi)𝑃conditionalsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖P(x_{i}|y_{i}) is different among clients. Following [61], each client is allocated random samples from only one domain.

On both tasks, we fine-tune a CLIP Vision Transformer (CLIP) model [5].

Besides, we fine-tune an XLM-Roberta-Base model on the following text dataset:

  • •

    XGLUE-NC [49]: This is a news classification task consisting of 10 classes. The news texts comprise five languages (English, Spanish, French, German, and Russian). We allocate one random language to each client, which naturally introduces domain shift among clients.

In addition, we evaluate a LLaMA-2-7B  model on the QA datasets.

  • •

    QA: The QA datasets consist of four commonly used question-answering datasets, i.e., SCIQ [50], OpenbookQA [51], PIQA [52], ARC-Easy and ARC-Challenge [53]. The datasets are transformed into classification tasks where the model determines the correct answer for each question and corresponding choices. We allocate the samples from one random dataset to each client, indicating the domain shift among clients.

D.2 Implementation Details

The CLIP model is pre-trained on the DataComp dataset and is adapted from https://github.com/openai/CLIP; the XLM-Roberta-Base model is adapted from https://huggingface.co/xlm-roberta-base; the LLaMA-2-7B model is adapted from https://huggingface.co/meta-llama/LLaMA-7b-chat-hf. In all training tasks, we freeze the embedding layers of the model and fix the classifier as commonly selected layers [32]. The values of adopted hyperparameters are summarized in Table 4.

Appendix E Limitations

One main limitation of our work is the theoretical results in Theorem 4.7 are restricted to the case where Assumptions 4.1-4.3 hold. Besides, the proposed layer selection strategy introduces additional computation costs, as discussed in Appendix C.
